723426f.title: Manhattan: State Street - Bowling Green Row
723426f.text:
State Street, east side, south from Bowling Green Row to Pearl Street,
showing a row of fashionable homes facing on Battery Park (right). Shown
in the foreground, is No. 7 Bowling 9reen, at the S.E. corner of State Street.
The farthest building shown, is Stewart's Store, (predecessor to John
Wanamaker in the Department Store line), which occupied the block between
Bridge and Pearl Streets. Stephen Whitney resided in one of the houses
facing Bowling Green. Today (1937), the U.S. Custom House rises here on
the area shown in the foreground, with the 12-story Battery Park Building
(former Stewart site) at its rear.
About 1860.
Ewing Galloway.
A4ae
ww~-
723426f.folder: State Street & Bowling Green Row, Manhattan, NY

716806f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716806f-b.text:
-- Bowling Grgen, a northward view up Broadway from
"Steemship Row", showing a view of Eew York's first park.
Note the iron railing around same and the lanterns thereupon.
In the center is a pool and fountain.
Early views (circcl850 and 61) show this latter feature
and which in subseduent views (1684) is absent, tho the pool
:6hained. The last date given is that of Produce Exchange
Building construction, replacing the buildings on the right.
To the left on Broadway, appear ovate shaped sewer pipes
and a partial excavation for same. These Were introduced in
1860 anu were 4x2.8 feet in diameter. In 18o4 vitrified pipe
was first laid. Across the foreground are suspended electric
wires and at the extreme right is an old street illuminating
gas lamp.
For dedication ceremony (April 6, 1938) see New York
City newspapers for February anu March. Views similar to this
are in these files and in a volume of newspaper clippings
titled "New York City Views" American History Dvision - Room 300
New York Public Library,several of whicn are credited to
the Consoliuated Edison Company.
Between 1861 and 1864
Rockwood Photo
E--Broa way north from Bowling Green
Thaddeus Wilderson  about 1900
522 W. 145th.Street
New York City

716814f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716814f-a.text:
Bowling Green: 'ew York's first park photographed southward
down Broadway. This thoroughfare is on the right and Battery Park
is just beyond. Buildings appearing through the trees are units
of the former residences that now form "Steamship Row." Above
same, in the Upper Bay, lies Governor's Island.
About 1875
Roege, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Mmainly the westerly side of this thoroughfare and its
Trinity Church at Wall Street.
1876

716808f.text:

716972f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716972f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green. Trinity Church is shown on
the west side of Broadway, north of Rector Street. In the foreground,
appears a Broadway street car; drawn by horses. hote gas 1ights on
street and overhead wire commuunications.

716809f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716809f-a.text:
Bowling Green Park: New Yorks first park, located
at the foot of Broadway. The buildings in the background
are upon the west side of that thoroughfare, extending
between Battery Place (left) and Morris Street (right).
The Columbia Building stands at the N. W. corner of the
1atter point. To the north is the Aldrich Court.
About 1885
Gift of the Urbrock Collection

716956f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716956f-a.text:
Broadway, east side, north from Bowling Green and showing prominently
the Seaboard National Bank (No. 18) and the Standard Oil Building (No. 26).
Subsequently,this latter corporation purchased the Bank site and erected
upon same. Eings Hand book of New York, 1892, carries an account of this
financial institution and a similar illustration on page 692.
1889.
Brown Brothers.

716971f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716971f-a.text:
Broadway, north trom new Battery Place. 1n the background is
Trinity Vhurch.

716967f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716967f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing
promuinently the easterly side of this thoroughfare.
Oe the right appears the Standard Oil Building and
the adjoining Seaboard National Bank. For details
and a comparative illustration see King's Handbook
of New York--pages 143 and 692.
About 1895

716953f-a.text:

the 17 story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11.
1899

716938f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716938f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing tho foot
of this important Manhattan thoroughfare. The City's
first park, the Green, is in the center behind the
street car. The buildings there are on the east side
and were later replaced with the outstanding Standard
Gil Building. At the left margin is No. 1 Broadway.
About 1900
Thomas 'V. Kennedy, photo
Thru Beecher Ogden
Museum Photo. Assn.

716935f-a.text:

and Beaver Street on the right, and showing mainly the east side of BroA dway
aoross Bowling Green.
September 20, 1906.

portion of the Washington Building and on the right, a part of the Produce

rown Brothers.

716804f-a.text:
Bowling Green, at the foot of Broadway, showing
the U. S. Custom House there, as photographed across

Street. On the right is State Street and Battery Park.

716927f.text:

dome of the Washington Building as viewed in a southward direction from
the Bowling Green Building. Ihn addition appears a portion of Battery
Park and the Upper Bay. This set consists of a negative and a positive.
July 27, 1920.

716945f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716945f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green. The intersection shown on the
right, is B)aver Strcet, with the 7-story Produce Building at the S.E. cor-
ner. The towered Standard Oil Co. Building (Nos. 8 to 26 Broadway) ocoupies
the N.E. corner. Prominent buildings shown on the left, (west side of
Broadway), and in the order of their appearance are the: Washington, Bowling
Green, Cdnard, Columbia, Adams, American Railway Eypress Co., Empire, Trinity
and Singer.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

716946f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716946f-a.text:
Broadway, north from both Battery Place and Beaver Street.
(At the left is Battery P1ace and at the right is Beaver Street. This
view shows Bowling Green in the centre foreground, which was originally
used by the Dutch, for bowling and a drinking place, a refuge from
their respective domestic havens.
About 1925.

716973f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716973f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing the start of this thorough-
fare that traverses the entire island.
September 1926.
Brown Brothers.

716968f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716968f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, with Battery Place on the left, and
Beaver Street on the right. Sandwiched between these building g1ants, is
Bowling Green, the first public park in Manhattan, surrounding which stood
the homes of Lord Cornwallis, Bord Howe, Sir Henry Clinton, George Washington,
General Gates, Benedict Arnold, Talleyrand and other famous personages of
American History. To-day (1937), we find encompassing same, the Washington,
Bowling Green, and Cunard Buildings on the west side of Broadway, and fac-
ing the curved Standard Oil Co. Building. On the right, a portion of the
U.S. Custom House obstructs a view of the Produce Exchange Building. The
spired edifices in the background, are the Singer and Woolworth Buildings.
February 4, 1927.
New York Edison Company.

716819f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716819f-a.text:
Bovling Green and the U.S. Custom Bouse, as viewed southward
along Broadway. Shown on the right, the west side of Broadway, and
in the order of their appearance are, the Cunard Building, the
Bowling Green Building, the Washington Building and Battery Park.
The curved building on the opposite side, is Nos. 8-26 Broadway, the
Standard Oil Company Building.
February 21, 1928
N. Y. Edison Company.

716933f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716933f-a.text:
(1)
Broadway, north from Battery Place, showing at the left, the Washington
Building (N.W. corner of Battery Place) and at the right the curved
structure of the Standard Oil Co. (N.E. corner of Beaver Street). Note the
Woolworth Building, up Broadway.
May 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The tower atop the Standard Oil Building as viewed in a northward
direction from the Produce Exchange Building. Broadway is on the left.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716933f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716933f-b.text:

Broadway, north from Battery Place, showing at the left, the Washington
Building (N.W. corner of Battery Place) and at the right the curved

May 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The tower atop the Standard Oil Building as viewed in a northward
direction from the Produce Exchange Building. Broadway is on the left.
August 28, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

716961f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716961f-b.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green (right) and showing mainly the
west side (left) of same. Note the apple vendors in front of the Cunard
Building. This was a feature of the early phases of the Depression. This
set consists of 2 views.
About 1930.

716812f-b.text:
(1)
Bowling Green: (A small triangular plot on the northern confines
of Battery Park), at the southern terminus of Broadway. Shown in the
Green, and facing the Cgstom House, is the heroic statue of Abraham De-
peyster the great-grandfather of Philip Van Cortlandt.

716965f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716965f-a.text:
Broadway, north from Bowling Green, showing W.P.A. employees engaged
in a street car track removal project. Note the Republican campaign
banner suspended aoross Broadway, soliciting the financial and clerical
workers of this district to vote for their presidential candidate, who as
it eventually evolved, failed to be elected; Franklin D. Roosevelt gaining
a second term.
August 25, 1936.
W.P.A. Photo.
Federal Art Project.

716934f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716934f-a.text:
Broadway, at Bowling Green, viewed northward from the U. S.
Custom House. Dominant on the right is the Standard Oil Building.
Opposed to same are the Cunard, Columbia and Fred F. French Build-
ings.
1938-9

716823f-b.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716823f-b.text:
Bowling Green viewed northward from Battery Place (in Views
1-2-3) showing the point where Broadway begins its existance.
Note the old horse car in view 1.
Visws 2-3-4 were taken to show the completion of the track
reroval by the W.P.A. This agency also rehabilitated tne park
and its fanous railing.
George L. Balgue  View 1: Nov. 1905
W. P. A. Photo  View 2-3-4: February 7, 1937
Five Borouths Project

716941f.title: Manhattan: Broadway - Battery Place
716941f.text:
(1)
Nos. 1, 5-11 and 13 to 27 Broadway, west side, north from Battery
Place (left) to Morris Street (right) as seen across Bowling Oreen.
Twe 12-story structure on the left (No. 1) is the Washington Building.
Adjacent to same is the 17-story Bowling Green Building, No. 5-11.
At the S.W. corner of Morris Street is the 5-story Stevens House,
No. 21-27. Across the roof of the latter appears the south side of
the 12-story Columbia Building, No. 29 Broadway, at the N.W. corner
of Morris Street.
September 25, 1906.
Brown Brothers.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.  C7  T AE  N N  1 O
(2)
The same in a southward direction (from Morris Street to Battery
Place). Note on the extreme left the Custom House under construction.
May 2, 1904.
Brown Brothers.

716821f-a.title: Manhattan: Broadway - State Street
716821f-a.text:
(1)
Bowling Green South, east from and including State Street,
to and including Broadway. Also shown is State Street, east side,
south from Bowling Green South, to but not including Bridge Street.
Bowling Green South was known as Steamship Row, and is now the
present site for the Custom House.
About 1885.
Brown Brothers.
(2)
The same, about forty-five years later, showing the United States
Custom House with Bowling Green in the foreground. Also shown is
Broadway, east side, south from but not including Beaver Street.
June 6, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
A view mainly of the New York Produce Exchange Building (No. 2
Broadway), the eastern boundary of the Green.
October 13, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
